title: Rachel Alvarado
text: Welcome to my website! My name is Rachel Alvarado and I am a fourth year Environmental Studies major attending UC Santa Barbara. I am interested in habitat conservation and environmental consulting and I intend to work with the city of Los Angeles upon graduating. This webpage showcases my studies, experience, and extracurriculars. This website is continuously updated to encompass my increasing accomplishments and interests.

title: Rachel Alvarado
text: Welcome to my website! My name is Rachel Alvarado and I am a fourth year Environmental Studies major attending UC Santa Barbara. I am interested in habitat conservation and environmental consulting and I intend to work with the city of Los Angeles upon graduating. This webpage showcases my studies, experience, and extracurriculars. This website is continuously updated to encompass my increasing accomplishments and interests.

title: Interests: Learn More About Me
text: Whether they could fit in the palm of my hand or crush me with their weight, I adore animals of all shapes and sizes. I have grown up with all sorts of pets my entire life and ensure that each one lives a spoiled life. I believe every life — no matter how small or seemingly insignificant — has value and deserves compassion. Animals are worthy of our respect, empathy, and protection. This belief is a driving force behind my passion for environmental science. I’m committed to making the world a better place, not just for people, but for the countless other lives we share it with. After all, the world was theirs before it was ever ours.

title: Education - Schools Attended
text:
University of California, Santa Barbara


Sep 2022 – Jun 2025


Bachelor of Science



Cumulative GPA: 3.7 (Honors/Cum Laude)



I transferred to UC Santa Barbara in 2022, initially as a chemistry major. However, by the end of my first year, I discovered a deep interest in environmental science. We are living in a critical era—where climate change accelerates, biodiversity declines, and pollution levels rise—yet political inaction and denial persist at the highest levels. This reality motivated me to change my major. Since then, I’ve found purpose in studying renewable energy, sustainable urban planning, building certification systems, and critically evaluating the effectiveness of environmental strategies. My natural skepticism pushed me to approach research and case studies with rigor and curiosity, questioning assumptions and seeking practical solutions. I’ve grown a lot during my time at UCSB—academically and personally—and have come to truly appreciate the campus and its vibrant community.












 Santa Monica College


Sep 2020 – May 2022


Associate’s Degree



Cumulative GPA: 3.4



I attended Santa Monica College from 2020 to 2022 during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, with most of my coursework taking place online. It wasn’t until my final semester that I was able to experience the campus in person, where I finally connected with peers and built meaningful friendships. My academic focus during this time was heavily centered on STEM, particularly chemistry and mathematics. It was at SMC that I discovered my passion for general chemistry and statistics and where I began to envision a career driven by curiosity, impact, and purpose.












 International Christian University


March 2024 – June 2024


Study Abroad Program


In Spring 2024, I participated in a trimester-long study abroad program at International Christian University (ICU) in Tokyo, Japan. The program offered valuable exposure to Japanese academic and cultural environments, and provided the opportunity to engage with a diverse international student community. Immersing myself in a completely unfamiliar setting challenged me in unexpected ways—academically, socially, and personally. While the experience was often overwhelming, it ultimately strengthened my adaptability, broadened my perspective, and taught me how to navigate discomfort and uncertainty with resilience.

title: Environemntal Statistics - Personal Data Problem
text:
library(tidyverse)  #general use
library(here) #file organization
library(gt) #creating tables
library(janitor) #cleaning data frames
library(readxl) #reading xl files
library (jpeg) #adding jpeg images

#read in data
my_data <- read_csv("/home/jovyan/ES-193DS/ENVS-193DS_homework-03/data/193DS - Personal data project - Sheet1 (1).csv") 



I am summarizing my data by taking the mean number of steps taken for each sleep category: less than 7 hours, 7–8 hours, 8–9 hours, 9–10 hours, and 10 or more hours, and comparing my daily step counts across different sleep durations. I sleep less when I have to get up early and be out of the house, so I think I will walk more compared to the days I am able to sleep in.




# Set ggplot theme
theme_set(theme_bw())

# Clean and categorize data
my_data <- my_data |> 
  clean_names() |> 
  #making columns based on sleep category
  mutate(sleep_category = cut(
    sleep_hours,
    breaks = c(-Inf, 7, 8, 9, 10, Inf),
    labels = c("Less than 7", "7–8", "8–9", "9–10", "10 or more"),
    right = FALSE)) #includes the lesser value

# Create plot and input x and y axis values from table
ggplot(my_data, 
       aes(x = sleep_category, 
           y = exercise_steps, 
           color = sleep_category)) +
  
  # Add jitter layer
  geom_jitter(shape = 1, height = 0, width = 0.2, alpha = 0.6) +
  
  # Colored filled mean points
  stat_summary(
    geom = "point", 
    fun = mean, 
    size = 4, 
    aes(color = sleep_category)) +

  # Label x and y axis and title
  labs(x = "Sleep Duration Category",
       y = "Number of Steps",
       title = "Daily Steps vs Sleep Duration Category") +

  # Remove legend 
  theme(legend.position = "none") +

  # Manually set color palette
  scale_color_manual(values = c(
    "Less than 7" = "red",
    "7–8" = "orange",
    "8–9" = "hotpink",
    "9–10" = "green",
    "10 or more" = "blue"
  )) 











Figure 1 - Less than 9 hours of sleep have higher step counts compared to sleeping 9 or more hours.
Scatterplot showing the relationship between categorized sleep duration and number of daily steps taken. Each open circle represents a singular day’s step count, colored by sleep duration category (total n = 35). Sleeping less than 9 hours is colored red, sleeping 7-8 hours is colored orange, sleeping 8-9 hours is colored hot pink, sleeping 9-10 hours is colored green, and sleeping 10 or more hours is colored blue. The larger filled dots indicate the average steps for each group. Data was collected by self recording hours of sleep and tracking through phone step count.




# Summarize mean steps by sleep category
summary_table <- my_data |> 
  group_by(sleep_category) |> 
  summarise(Average_Steps = round(mean(exercise_steps), 1)) |> 
  arrange(factor(sleep_category, levels = c("Less than 7", "7–8", "8–9", "9–10", "10 or more")))

# Create GT table
summary_table |> 
  gt() |> 
  # labeling columns and title
  cols_label(
    sleep_category = "Sleep Duration Category",
    Average_Steps = "Average Steps"
  ) |> 
  tab_header(
    title = "Average Daily Steps by Sleep Duration"
  )







Average Daily Steps by Sleep Duration


Sleep Duration Category
Average Steps




Less than 7
8376.2


7–8
7462.8


8–9
8746.2


9–10
3056.5


10 or more

title: Education - Noteable Coursework
text:
Renewable Energy Systems – UCSB



Examining economic policies


Energy storage


Wind, solar, tidal, geothermal energy systems



Green Building – UCSB



Systems to reduce energy demand


Implementing renewable energy and materials


Cost implications


Analyzing energy efficient systems



Geographic Information System (GIS) – UCSB



Capture, manage, analyze, and share spatial data


Create maps based on findings


Windows proficiency


Generate clear spatial questions



Environmental Statistics – UCSB



Understand basic probability and statistics


Select statistical analyses for hypotheses


Analyze and visualize data using R coding


Ensure reproducibility and collaboration


Interpret results in environmental contexts



Engineering and Environmental Geology – UCSB



Recording and analyzing aerial imagery


Analyzing fire, flood, air quality hazards


Analyzing and plotting water level data


Examining oil well safety


Reporting and presenting findings



Biology Laboratory – Los Angeles Community College



Microscope proficiency


Animal behavior


Osmosis and diffusion


Cellular respiration


Gel electrophoresis



Conservation Planning – UCSB



Developing conservation plans for different species and ecosystems


Miradi profficiency


Fundamental objectives charts and webs


Working with Northern Chumash Council tribe for erosion control

title: Interests: Learn More About Me
text: Whether they could fit in the palm of my hand or crush me with their weight, I adore animals of all shapes and sizes. I have grown up with all sorts of pets my entire life and ensure that each one lives a spoiled life. I believe every life — no matter how small or seemingly insignificant — has value and deserves compassion. Animals are worthy of our respect, empathy, and protection. This belief is a driving force behind my passion for environmental science. I’m committed to making the world a better place, not just for people, but for the countless other lives we share it with. After all, the world was theirs before it was ever ours.

title: Interests: Learn More About Me
text:
Adventures Outside


I spend much of my free time at the beach, on trails, and exploring the outdoors. These moments ground me and inspire my commitment to the environment.

title: Interests: Learn More About Me
text:
Gardening


Gardening was a passion I discovered during my time at UC Santa Barbara. It began with volunteering at the Methodist Church Garden where I learned the fundamentals of watering, weeding, mulching, and harvesting fresh vegetables. The experience was new, calming, and rewarding. This foundation prepared me for my next role with the Department of Public Worms at the ECP Student Farm. While the tasks were similar, the sense of community and shared purpose made the work even more fulfilling. Gardening has since become more than a hobby. It is a meaningful way for me to connect with the land, contribute to sustainability, and work with my community.

title: Extracurriculars: Learn More About Me
text:
Collaborating with the Chumash Community


I’ve had the privilege to learn from and work alongside members of the Chumash community. This experience helped me better understand Indigenous stewardship, traditional ecological knowledge, and cultural history.

title: Interests: Learn More About Me
text:
Collaborating with the Community


I’ve been fortunate to collaborate with a variety of groups within the UCSB community on projects related to land planning and sustainable development. With LEED (Leaders in Environmental and Engineering Design), I contributed to the certification of Bren Hall, gaining firsthand experience in green building standards. I also partnered with UCSB leadership to assess the Isla Vista Theater and propose sustainable improvements for its infrastructure. Additionally, I had the meaningful opportunity to work alongside the Northern Chumash Tribal Council, surveying hillside erosion and exploring effective solutions to stabilize the region’s sandy soils. These experiences deepened my understanding of environmental stewardship and the importance of collaborative, place-based approaches to sustainability.
